case_name: Two appellants (brothers) v. Board of Revenue and Collector of Pilibhit

anchor.surface_text: U. P. Agricultural Income-tax Act  U. P. Act III of 1949 , hereinafter called the Act.
Section 5 of the Act provides for a determination of agricultural income,

section 6 provides for the companyputation of such income in two alternative ways one method proceeds on the basis of a certain multiple of rent and the other on the gross proceeds of sale of the produce of the lands. The section, as it stood at the relevant time, reads as follows 6.  1  The agricultural income mentioned in sub-clauses  i ,  ii  and  iii  of clause  b  of sub-section  1  of section 2 shall, at the option of the assessee, be companyputed in accordance with clause  a  or clause  b  of sub-section  2  Provided that an assessee who has once exercised his option shall number be entitled to vary the method of companyputation except with the permission of the Board of Revenue.  2   a . Subject to such deduction in respect of agricultural calamities as may be prescribed, the income shall be deemed to be such multiple, number exceeding 7 1/2 per cent. of the rent of the land, calculated at the latest sanction rent rates applicable to hereditary tenants of similar class of soil as the Board of Revenue may fix for each district or portion thereof Provided that the Board of Revenue may direct that the multiple for calculating income from land newly brought under cultivation shall for the specified number of years be such lower figure as may be specified, or  b  the income shall be the gross proceeds of sale of all the produce of the land subject to the following deductions  then the deductions are stated .

concepts.interpretation: Provides two alternative methods for computation of agricultural income at assessee's option, but once chosen, cannot vary without Board of Revenue's permission per proviso to sub-s (1). Proviso unqualified, applies across years.

issues.text: Whether the proviso to sub-section (1) of section 6 restricts variation in the method of computation only within any one assessment year, allowing free variation in subsequent years without permission of the Board of Revenue, or whether it prohibits variation across years without such permission?

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants it was contended that the restriction imposed by the proviso on variation in the method of computation was limited to any one year and the assessee was at liberty to vary the method in any other year without the permission of the Board. The High Court did not accept this as correct...

issues.text: Whether the Board of Revenue applied its mind when refusing permission to the appellants to vary the method of computation under the proviso to section 6(1)?

anchor.surface_text: Next, it has been argued that the Board of Revenue did not apply its mind when it refused permission to the appellants. It appears that the application of the appellants was noted on by an officer...

issues.text: Whether the proviso to sub-section (1) of section 6 confers unfettered discretion on the Board of Revenue without principles for guidance, rendering it violative of Article 14 of the Constitution?
Whether the appellants are entitled to writ of certiorari quashing the order of the Board of Revenue refusing permission to vary the method of computation under the proviso to section 6(1)?

anchor.surface_text: a writ of certiorari quashing the order of the Board of Revenue refusing permission to the appellants to vary the method of computation under the proviso to sub-section (1) of section 6.

issues.text: Whether the appellants are entitled to writ of mandamus directing the Board of Revenue and Collector to issue forms for submitting returns using the multiple method under clause (a) of section 6(2)?

anchor.surface_text: a writ of mandamus to be issued against the Board of Revenue and the Collector of Pilibhit, respondents herein, directing them to issue suitable forms to the appellants for submitting returns...

arguments.claim: The restriction imposed by the proviso to sub-section (1) of section 6 on variation in the method of computation was limited to any one year and the assessee was at liberty to vary the method in any other year without the permission of the Board of Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants it was contended that the restriction imposed by the proviso on variation in the method of computation was limited to any one year and the assessee was at liberty to vary the method in any other year without the permission of the Board.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: sent of the Income-tax Officer and upon such companyditions as the Income-tax Officer may impose. We do number see how this provision helps the appell

arguments.court_reasoning: No warrant for reading limitation into unqualified language; proviso construed per scheme of section 6 and section 15(4); avoids conflict.

arguments.claim: The substantive part of sub-section (1) of section 6 gave unfettered right to choose method but proviso cut it down such that once option exercised, no variation without Board permission; no limitation to one year.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court said that the substantive part of sub- section (1) no doubt gave an unfettered right to an assessee to choose any of the two methods of computation but this right was cut down by the proviso, which said that an assessee who had once exercised an option could not vary the method of computation except with the permission of the Board of Revenue.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: sent of the Income-tax Officer and upon such comp

arguments.court_reasoning: Court in agreement with High Court view.

arguments.claim: The Board of Revenue did not apply its mind when it refused permission to the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Next, it has been argued that the Board of Revenue did not apply its mind when it refused permission to the appellants. It appears that the application of the appellants was noted on by an officer...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ard. Obviously, the Board in the exercise of its discretion must act reasonably and must take into companysideration the relevant factors including th

arguments.court_reasoning: Note considered relevant factors like administrative difficulties; endorsed by Deputy Secretary and approved by Senior Member.

arguments.claim: The proviso to sub-section (1) of section 6 gives unfettered discretion to the Board without principles for guidance, capable of discriminatory application, violative of Article 14.
arguments.court_reasoning: Discretionary power not necessarily discriminatory, especially for high authority; section 6 provides guidance; must act reasonably.

arguments.claim: Provisions of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 (proviso to section 2(11)(i)(a) and section 13) support interpretation allowing variation across years.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants our attention has been drawn to the proviso to section 2 (11) (i) (a) and section 13 of the Indian Income- tax Act, 1922. We do not think that these provisions help us to determine the true scope and effect of the proviso to sub section (1) of section 6 of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: anyld be made without the permission of the Board of Revenue. We are in agreement with the view, expressed by the High Court. It is indeed true, as ha

arguments.court_reasoning: Different language, scheme, and purpose; section 13 on regular accounting method, no option; proviso on newly set up business previous year.

arguments.claim: Entitled to writ of certiorari quashing the order of the Board of Revenue refusing permission to vary the method of computation under proviso to section 6(1).

anchor.surface_text: a writ of certiorari quashing the order of the Board of Revenue refusing permission to the appellants to vary the method of computation under the proviso to sub-section (1) of section 6.

arguments.court_reasoning: No error in Board's order; no fundamental right infringed.

arguments.claim: Entitled to writ of mandamus directing Board of Revenue and Collector to issue forms for returns using multiple method under section 6(2)(a).

anchor.surface_text: a writ of mandamus to be issued against the Board of Revenue and the Collector of Pilibhit, respondents herein, directing them to issue suitable forms to the appellants for submitting returns...

arguments.court_reasoning: No legal right to vary method without permission; no fundamental right.

arguments.claim: The proviso to section 6(1) is unqualified and once option exercised, no variation without Board permission across years.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court did not accept this as correct and held that there was no warrant for reading such a limitation in the proviso, the language of which was unqualified and meant what it said, that once the option was exercised, no variation could be made without the permission of the Board of Revenue.

arguments.claim: Proviso must be construed with reference to language used and scheme of section 6; no insertion of 'in any one year'.

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with the view, expressed by the High Court. It is indeed true... That does not necessarily mean that the restriction imposed by the proviso to sub-section (1) of section 6 is limited to one year only. The proviso must be construed with reference to the language used and the scheme of section 6.

arguments.claim: No right to vary computation method after filing return; section 15(4) allows only corrections of mistakes/omissions; petitioner's interpretation causes conflict with section 15(4).

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of the Act is that every assessee has to furnish a return by a prescribed date and once he has furnished the return, he can, under sub-section (4) of section 15, only correct the mistakes or fill in the omissions in the return...

arguments.claim: Indian Income-tax Act provisions distinguishable as different language, scheme, and purpose from U.P. Act section 6 proviso.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that these provisions help us to determine the true scope and effect of the proviso to sub section (1) of section 6 of the Act. For one thing, the language is different for another, the scheme and purpose of these different provisions is also not the same.

arguments.claim: Board of Revenue applied its mind; relevant considerations in note (ease, tax reduction motive, admin difficulties); approved by senior officer.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the application of the appellants was noted on by an officer of the Board of Revenue this note was put up to the Deputy Secretary... The High Court has pointed out that when a senior officer signs a note submitted to him, it shows that he approves of it.

arguments.claim: Proviso discretion not violative of Article 14; not unfettered/discriminatory; section 6 provides guidance; high authority must act reasonably; cites precedents.
No permission to adduce additional evidence on permissions granted to others; not sitting in appeal over Board; facts unknown.
U.P. Agricultural Income-tax Amendment Act, 1953 not applicable to 1952-53 assessment as came after year-end.

anchor.surface_text: We may state here that by the U. P. Agricultural Income-tax Amendment Act, 1953 (U. P. Act XIV of 1953), the proviso to sub- section (1) of section 6 was deleted... It is conceded, however, that the relevant provisions of this amending Act which came into force on July 1, 1953, after the close of the year 1952-1953...

arguments.claim: No infringement of fundamental right; writ petitions fail.

holdings.text: Once the option is exercised, no variation could be made without the permission of the Board of Revenue. There was no warrant for reading such a limitation in the proviso, the language of which was unqualified.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court did not accept this as correct and held that there was no warrant for reading such a limitation in the proviso, the language of which was unqualified and meant what it said, that once the option was exercised, no variation could be made without the permission of the Board of Revenue. We are in agreement with the view, expressed by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with High Court; plain unqualified language; no basis to limit to one year; construed per language and scheme of s6 and s15(4) to avoid conflict.

holdings.text: The proviso must be construed with reference to the language used and the scheme of section 6; scheme requires return by date, revised only for mistakes/omissions under s15(4), no right to vary method after filing.

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with the view, expressed by the High Court. It is indeed true... That does not necessarily mean that the restriction imposed by the proviso to sub-section (1) of section 6 is limited to one year only. The proviso must be construed with reference to the language used and the scheme of section 6. That section mentions two alternative methods of computation, and by the substantive part of sub-section (1) gives the assessee an option to adopt any one of the two methods then comes the proviso which says that once the option is exercised, there can be no variation without the permission of the Board of Revenue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction with s15(4); avoids conflict if variation allowed within year via revised return; no mention in s15(4) of method variation.

holdings.text: Provisions of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 do not help determine scope of proviso to s6(1) of U.P. Act as language, scheme and purpose different.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes on language, scheme, purpose; s13 no option, proviso for new business previous year.

holdings.text: The Board of Revenue applied its mind when refusing permission as note considered relevant factors and approved by senior officer.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the application of the appellants was noted on by an officer of the Board of Revenue this note was put up to the Deputy Secretary... The High Court has pointed out that when a senior officer signs a note submitted to him, it shows that he approves of it. In these circumstances we are unable to accept the contention that the Board failed to apply its mind when permission to vary the method of computation was refused to the appellants on the contrary, the note shows that all the relevant considerations were kept in mind.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Note addressed ease, tax motive, admin difficulties; endorsed by Deputy Secy, approved by Senior Member.

holdings.text: Proviso to s6(1) not violative of Article 14 as discretion not unfettered; s6 provides guidance; Board must act reasonably considering relevant factors.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents: discretion to high authority not per se discriminatory; s6 advantages/disadvantages guide; must consider relevant factors reasonably.

holdings.text: No permission to adduce additional evidence to show permissions in other cases as facts unknown and not sitting in appeal over Board.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court not appellate over Board on facts; other cases facts unknown.

holdings.text: Appeals fail and must be dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, the appeals fail and must be dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reasons above on interpretation, application of mind, Art14.

holdings.text: Writ petitions fail as no infringement of fundamental right.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No merits in claims; no fundamental right violated.

holdings.text: Amending Act 1953 provisions have no effect on 1952-53 assessment as came after year-end.

anchor.surface_text: It is conceded, however, that the relevant provisions of this amending Act which came into force on July 1, 1953, after the close of the year 1952-1953 (the year closing at the end of June) have no effect on the assessment of 1952-53.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amending Act force July 1, 1953 after 1952-53 year-end; conceded.

precedents.citation: Matajog Dobey v. H. C. Bhari

anchor.surface_text: In Matajog Dobey v. H. C. Bhari and Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar this court had said that a discretionary power is number necessarily a discriminatory power and that abuse of power is number to be easily assumed where the discretions companyfided number to a petty official but to a high authority.

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with the view, expressed by the High Court. It is indeed true... That does not necessarily mean that the restriction imposed by the proviso to sub-section (1) of section 6 is limited to one year only. The proviso must be construed with reference to the language used and the scheme of section 6. That section mentions two alternative methods of computation, and by the substantive part of sub-section (1) gives the assessee an option to adopt any one of the two methods then comes the proviso which says that once the option is exercised, there can be no variation without the permission of the Board of Revenue.

For the reasons given above, the appeals fail and must be dismissed. The writ petitions must also share the same fate, for, in the views which we have expressed, numberquestion of the infringement of any fundamental right arises.

edges.explanation: Issue i1 concerns interpretation of proviso to s6(1) of the U.P. Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1949.
The issue questions whether the Board applied its mind, directly addressing the natural justice doctrine focused on applying mind and consideration of relevant factors as in c14.
Issue i3 requires application of concept c10 under Art14.
Issue i3 on Art14 violation requires a holding like h5 to resolve.
The issue explicitly questions entitlement to 'writ of certiorari', directly addressing the concept of Writ of Certiorari.
